title: Fix: 3537 exempts authoritative Pydantic models from schema contracts cheks
body:
## Description
- remove all Pydantic v1 compatibility code — the codebase now requires and uses only Pydantic v2 APIs
- add support for Pydantic models with discriminated union `RootModel` types in schema generation and contract enforcement
- rework schema contract handling to separate resource-defined hints from data-derived hints, so Pydantic model columns bypass contract checks when marked as authoritative
- rewrite `merge_table` to work without `diff_table`, fixing reference merging and treating `incremental` as a compound property
- suppress Pydantic deprecation warnings and fix instance-level attribute access to prepare for Pydantic v3
- resolves #3537 (if model authoritative)
- supports Pydantic models with discriminated fields to validate event streams
- allow Pydantic models on arrow and model items
- fully implement schema contracts on model items
- removes dead Pydantic 1 code paths
- resolves issues with Athena not falling back to append in some cases

title: feat: composable marimo widgets
body:
## Summary
This adds composable widgets to `dlt` built with `marimo`. A widget is **composable** because you can give it inputs and read its outputs. For `marimo < 0.19`, it wasn't possible to pass inputs.

This follows-up #3021 (read-only widgets) and #3080 (closed in favor of this one)

## Content
- instructions on how to create widgets
- updated previous read-only widgets (schema viewer and load package viewer)
- add simple pipeline selector widget
- add a dependency to `mowidgets`, which implements the widget logic. It's MIT-licensed library and hosted on GitHub. I created it on my personal time.

## Open question
I don't think creating a new `dlt[widgets]` group is the best idea. This should probably be in `dlt[workspace]`. Though, we would need to bump the `marimo` notebook significantly from 0.14 to 0.19. IMHO, we shouldn't support old dependencies in dev-tooling (e.g., drop old marimo versions). This is different than pipelines, sources, and destinations where backwards compatibility is essential

## Next steps
- Build more "single-purpose" widgets
- Rebuild the dlt Dashboard to use composable widgets. 
  - There is no immediate gain, but it will improve maintainability and ensure parity between "dashboard" and "interactive widgets" moving forward
- Add public documentation
- Add tests to individual widgets, especially those used in the dashboard. We can focus on critical paths.

---

title: Add agent checks for automated PR review
body:
## Description

Add 14 agent check files in `.continue/agents/` for automated PR review. These checks encode project-specific conventions that require human judgment — things that existing linters and CI can't catch.

### Checks included

| Check | What it reviews |
|---|---|
| `identifier-normalization` | All identifiers pass through schema naming normalizer |
| `module-hierarchy` | `dlt/common/` stays generic, protocols for cross-module interfaces |
| `thread-safety` | Concurrent code paths (load jobs, sinks) are thread-safe |
| `deprecation-guidelines` | Breaking changes follow DltDeprecationWarning lifecycle |
| `destination-implementation` | New destinations follow factory/config/client pattern |
| `configuration-patterns` | @configspec usage, TSecretValue typing, credential specs |
| `exception-handling` | DltException hierarchy with Terminal/Transient mixins |
| `public-api-exports` | New public items added to `__all__` |
| `column-hints-merging` | Adapter hints merge correctly instead of overwriting |
| `cli-output-conventions` | CLI uses fmt not logger, error messages use backticks |
| `documentation-sync` | User-facing changes have corresponding docs |
| `test-coverage` | Tests are parallel-safe, use uniq_id, cover edge cases |
| `security-review` | No hardcoded creds, SQL injection prevention |
| `agent-docs-maintenance` | Agent check files stay current when conventions change |

Also updates `.gitignore` to track `.continue/agents/` while ignoring other `.continue/` contents.

## Related Issues

N/A — this adds AI-assisted review infrastructure.

## Additional Context

Each check was derived from:
- Analyzing `CONTRIBUTING.md`, `tox.ini`, `mypy.ini`, CI workflows
- Reviewing comments on ~30 recent merged PRs to identify recurring reviewer feedback
- Understanding the destination/configuration/schema architecture

Checks intentionally exclude anything already caught by deterministic CI tools (mypy, flake8, uv lock, etc.).

title: feat: `Dataset.write()`
body:
Users of `dlt.Dataset` want a simple way to write data back to the dataset.

Use cases:
- manually review data and push corrected records
- simple way to add records if you don't have access to the original `dlt.Pipeline` used to create the dataset

## Other motivations
This interface will simplify data-centric operations involved in:
- storing data quality checks results on destination
- creating a graph of datasets where the "internal pipeline" of dataset is used
- integrate with orchestration frameworks

## Specs
- Look at `WritableDataset.save()` from `dlt-plus`
- Add `Dataset.write()` in `dlt` (this aligns with `pipeline.run()` operation)
  - Alternatives: `.write_to()`, `.load_into()`, `.load_table()`
- create an internal `dlt.Pipeline` named `_dlt_dataset_{dataset_name}`
- find a way for the internal pipeline to use the `dlt.Schema` from the `dlt.Dataset` instance; this way, this schema should evolve when `Dataset.load()` is used
- potential API
  ```python
  def write(
    self: dlt.Dataset,
    data: TDataItems,
    *,
    table_name: str,
    write_disposition: TWriteDisposition = "append",
    normalize: bool = False,
  ) -> LoadInfo: ...
  ```
  - `write_disposition` is useful to determine if we should append or modify existing records
  - `normalize` allows the user to decide to enable normalization (which might create more tables)
- can accept a `dlt.Relation` as input


## Out of scope
- `Dataset.load()` doesn't have to support 1-to-1 the `dlt.Pipeline.run()` method; if user needs full range of config, then they should create a pipeline

title: Unexpected write_disposition behavior when moving data from S3 to Databricks
body:
### dlt version

1.5.0

### Describe the problem

When write_disposition is set as a hint on the source like below it is ignored (defaults to append),

```
s3_orders = filesystem(
      bucket_url="s3://oc-test-data-load-tool-dbx/oc_data_raw/orders",
      file_glob="*.jsonl"
    ).apply_hints(incremental=dlt.sources.incremental("modification_date"), write_disposition="replace")
```

and when write_disposition is set at the pipeline level, it is used but incremental loading is ignored.
```
    pipeline = dlt.pipeline(
        import_schema_path="schemas/import",
        export_schema_path="schemas/export",
        pipeline_name="s3_to_databricks",
        destination="databricks",
        staging=dlt.destinations.filesystem("s3://oc-test-data-load-tool-dbx/oc_data_staging"),
        dataset_name="oc_data_bronze",
        dev_mode=False,
        progress="tqdm"
    )
    orders_load_info = pipeline.run((s3_orders | read_jsonl()).with_name('orders'), write_disposition="replace")
    logging.info(orders_load_info)
```


### Expected behavior

I expect the script to do a destructive replace when write_disposition="replace" is set at the source level, and I expect DLT to correctly use incremental loading even when the write_disposition is set at the pipeline level. (I do not expect behavior to be different based on whether write_disposition is set at the pipeline level or the source level)

### Steps to reproduce

Here is my full code with the write_disposition set as part of a hint: (Note that I am not running it as a lambda function, I am running on my local machine)

```import dlt
from dlt.sources.filesystem import filesystem, read_jsonl
import logging
from datetime import datetime

def lambda_handler(event={}, context=None):
    s3_orders = filesystem(
      bucket_url="s3://oc-test-data-load-tool-dbx/oc_data_raw/orders",
      file_glob="*.jsonl"
    ).apply_hints(incremental=dlt.sources.incremental("modification_date"), write_disposition="append")

    s3_order_line_items = filesystem(
      bucket_url="s3://oc-test-data-load-tool-dbx/oc_data_raw/order_line_items",
      file_glob="*.jsonl"
    ).apply_hints(incremental=dlt.sources.incremental("modification_date"), write_disposition="append")

    s3_promotions = filesystem(
      bucket_url="s3://oc-test-data-load-tool-dbx/oc_data_raw/promotions",
      file_glob="*.jsonl"
    ).apply_hints(incremental=dlt.sources.incremental("modification_date"), write_disposition="replace")

    s3_products = filesystem(
      bucket_url="s3://oc-test-data-load-tool-dbx/oc_data_raw/products",
      file_glob="*.jsonl"
    ).apply_hints(incremental=dlt.sources.incremental("modification_date"), write_disposition="replace")

    s3_customers = filesystem(
      bucket_url="s3://oc-test-data-load-tool-dbx/oc_data_raw/customers",
      file_glob="*.jsonl"
    ).apply_hints(incremental=dlt.sources.incremental("modification_date"), write_disposition="replace")

    pipeline = dlt.pipeline(
        import_schema_path="schemas/import",
        export_schema_path="schemas/export",
        pipeline_name="s3_to_databricks",
        destination="databricks",
        staging=dlt.destinations.filesystem("s3://oc-test-data-load-tool-dbx/oc_data_staging"),
        dataset_name="oc_data_bronze",
        dev_mode=False,
        progress="tqdm"
    )

    promotions_load_info = pipeline.run((s3_promotions | read_jsonl()).with_name('promotions'))
    logging.info(promotions_load_info)
    products_load_info = pipeline.run((s3_products | read_jsonl()).with_name('products'))
    logging.info(products_load_info)
    orders_load_info = pipeline.run((s3_orders | read_jsonl()).with_name('orders'))
    logging.info(orders_load_info)
    order_line_items_load_info = pipeline.run((s3_order_line_items | read_jsonl()).with_name('order_line_items'))
    logging.info(order_line_items_load_info)
    customers_load_info = pipeline.run((s3_customers | read_jsonl()).with_name('customers'))
    logging.info(customers_load_info)

if __name__=="__main__":
    lambda_handler()
```

The easiest way to replicate this would be to put a simple test json file into a bucket in s3, run the pipeline, then put an additional file into the s3 bucket, and run the pipeline again (write_disposition should be set to replace). You will see two _dlt_load_id's in the data:

```
select _dlt_load_id, count(*) FROM oc_data_bronze.promotions
GROUP BY _dlt_load_id;
```


To see the other error, you'll need to move the write_disposition to the pipeline level as shown below (I have a couple with write_disposition set to append but those can be ignored):

```
import dlt
from dlt.sources.filesystem import filesystem, read_jsonl
import logging
from datetime import datetime

def lambda_handler(event={}, context=None):
    s3_orders = filesystem(
      bucket_url="s3://oc-test-data-load-tool-dbx/oc_data_raw/orders",
      file_glob="*.jsonl"
    ).apply_hints(incremental=dlt.sources.incremental("modification_date"))

    s3_order_line_items = filesystem(
      bucket_url="s3://oc-test-data-load-tool-dbx/oc_data_raw/order_line_items",
      file_glob="*.jsonl"
    ).apply_hints(incremental=dlt.sources.incremental("modification_date"))

    s3_promotions = filesystem(
      bucket_url="s3://oc-test-data-load-tool-dbx/oc_data_raw/promotions",
      file_glob="*.jsonl"
    ).apply_hints(incremental=dlt.sources.incremental("modification_date"))

    s3_products = filesystem(
      bucket_url="s3://oc-test-data-load-tool-dbx/oc_data_raw/products",
      file_glob="*.jsonl"
    ).apply_hints(incremental=dlt.sources.incremental("modification_date"))

    s3_customers = filesystem(
      bucket_url="s3://oc-test-data-load-tool-dbx/oc_data_raw/customers",
      file_glob="*.jsonl"
    ).apply_hints(incremental=dlt.sources.incremental("modification_date"))

    pipeline = dlt.pipeline(
        import_schema_path="schemas/import",
        export_schema_path="schemas/export",
        pipeline_name="s3_to_databricks",
        destination="databricks",
        staging=dlt.destinations.filesystem("s3://oc-test-data-load-tool-dbx/oc_data_staging"),
        dataset_name="oc_data_bronze",
        dev_mode=False,
        progress="tqdm"
    )

    promotions_load_info = pipeline.run((s3_promotions | read_jsonl()).with_name('promotions'), write_disposition="replace")
    logging.info(promotions_load_info)
    products_load_info = pipeline.run((s3_products | read_jsonl()).with_name('products'), write_disposition="replace")
    logging.info(products_load_info)
    orders_load_info = pipeline.run((s3_orders | read_jsonl()).with_name('orders'), write_disposition="append")
    logging.info(orders_load_info)
    order_line_items_load_info = pipeline.run((s3_order_line_items | read_jsonl()).with_name('order_line_items'), write_disposition="append")
    logging.info(order_line_items_load_info)
    customers_load_info = pipeline.run((s3_customers | read_jsonl()).with_name('customers'), write_disposition="replace")
    logging.info(customers_load_info)

if __name__=="__main__":
    lambda_handler()
```

Run the pipeline with one file in the source S3 bucket, then add another and run again. You will see that the target table in Databricks has data from both S3 files, but only one single _dlt_load_id, implying that a destructive replace was performed, but both files were read when only the latest one should have been. You can also further confirm this in the logs for the second run by noting that start_value is set to None (it should be the date of your first load).

> {"written_at":"2025-01-30T17:01:21.635Z","written_ts":1738256481635656000,"component_name":"s3_to_databricks","process":12821,"msg":"Bind incremental on filesystem_products with initial_value: None, start_value: None, end_value: None","type":"log","logger":"dlt","thread":"MainThread","level":"INFO","module":"__init__","line_no":483,"version":{"dlt_version":"1.5.0","pipeline_name":"s3_to_databricks"}}

macOS

3.11

title: qol: variant column generated by normalizer should have `description` field set
dlt.Relations `with_load_id_col()` crashes for data loads with multiple nested branches
body:
### dlt version

1.21.0

### Describe the problem

When running `dataset.table("...").with_load_id_col()` on a child table that has "parallel child branches" there is a chance that the program crashes with the error:
`dlt.dataset.exceptions.LineageFailedException: Failed to resolve SQL query against the schema received: Unknown column: _dlt_parent_id`

This is due to `schema_utils.get_all_parent_child_references_from_root` iterating depth first from root which might explore unrelated branches first.

### Expected behavior

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

This crashes:
```python
import dlt

data = [
    {
        "id": 1,
        "orders": [{"order_id": 101, "total_amount": 100.00}],  # branch: user__orders
        "profiles": [{"type": "personal"}]  # branch: user__profiles
    },
    {
        "id": 2,
        "orders": [{"order_id": 101, "total_amount": 100.00}],  # branch: user__orders
        "profiles": [{"type": "personal"}]  # branch: user__profiles
    }
]


@dlt.resource(name="users")
def users():
    yield data

# Run pipeline
pipeline = dlt.pipeline(
    pipeline_name="test_bug",
    destination="duckdb",
    dev_mode=True
)
pipeline.run(users(), dataset_name="test")

rel = pipeline.dataset().table("user__profiles").with_load_id_col().df()
```

This works:
```python
import dlt

data = [
    {
        "id": 1,
        # "orders": [{"order_id": 101, "total_amount": 100.00}],  # branch: user__orders
        "profiles": [{"type": "personal"}]  # branch: user__profiles
    },
    {
        "id": 2,
        # "orders": [{"order_id": 101, "total_amount": 100.00}],  # branch: user__orders
        "profiles": [{"type": "personal"}]  # branch: user__profiles
    }
]

@dlt.resource(name="users")
def users():
    yield data

# Run pipeline
pipeline = dlt.pipeline(
    pipeline_name="test_bug",
    destination="duckdb",
    dev_mode=True
)
pipeline.run(users(), dataset_name="test")

rel = pipeline.dataset().table("user__profiles").with_load_id_col().df()
```

### Operating system

Other, macOS

### Runtime environment

Local

### Python version

3.13

title: OOM (Memory Leak/High Consumption) when extracting millions of Parquet files from S3 via Arrow batches
body: ### dlt version 1.20.0 ### Describe the problem I am using dlt for load of Parquet files from S3 to BigQuery. The bucket is pretty big (over milion files). I need to do an incremental load. File sizes differe between 20 kB up to 200 MB. I also want to preserve file url and hive partitions encoded in that url as additional columns in my target table. However, I don't think this matters in this case. Here are my utils for extracting hive partitions from file paths and adding them as columns in the destination (any better idea how to do it?): ```python import pyarrow as pa import pyarrow.dataset as ds from pyarrow import parquet as pq def extract_partitions(item: FileItemDict, schema: pa.Schema) -> FileItemDict: partitioning = ds.HivePartitioning(schema) expression = partitioning.parse(item["file_url"]) partitions = ds.get_partition_keys(expression) item["partitions"] = partitions logger.debug("Extracted partitions: %r", partitions) return item def _add_scalar_column( batch: pa.RecordBatch, column_name: str, value, value_type: pa.DataType ) -> pa.RecordBatch: """Efficiently add a scalar column without creating intermediate list.""" scalar = pa.scalar(value, type=value_type) column = pa.repeat(scalar, len(batch)) logger.debug("Adding column: %r", column_name) return batch.append_column(column_name, column) def _add_extra_columns(batch, columns: dict) -> pa.RecordBatch: for column_name, column_info in columns.items(): batch = _add_scalar_column( batch, column_name, column_info["value"], column_info["value_type"] ) return batch @dlt.transformer def read_parquet_and_add_hive_columns( files: Iterable[FileItemDict], columns_mapper: Callable[[FileItemDict], dict], batch_size: int = 1000, ) -> Iterator[TDataItems]: for file in files: file_url = unquote(file["file_url"]) columns = columns_mapper(file) logger.info( "Open file: %s [%s]", file_url, humanize.naturalsize(file["size_in_bytes"]) ) with ( file.open() as source_file, pq.ParquetFile(source_file, pre_buffer=True) as parquet_file, ): for batch in parquet_file.iter_batches(batch_size=batch_size): yield _add_extra_columns(batch, columns) logger.info( "Finished extracting file: %s [%s]", file_url, humanize.naturalsize(file["size_in_bytes"]), ) ``` Here's my resource definition: ```python PARTITION_SCHEMA = pa.schema( [ ("projectid", pa.string()), ("year", pa.int32()), ("month", pa.int32()), ("day", pa.int32()), ] ) def columns_mapper(file: FileItemDict) -> dict: partitions = file["partitions"] return { "project_id": { "value": partitions["projectid"], "value_type": pa.string(), }, "event_date": { "value": date(partitions["year"], partitions["month"], partitions["day"]), "value_type": pa.date32(), }, "file_url": { "value": file["file_url"], "value_type": pa.string(), }, } @dlt.resource def event_store(bucket_url: str, event: str, last_ts: datetime = None) -> DltResource: logger.info("Scan path: %s", path) files = filesystem( credentials=dlt.secrets["sources.event_store.credentials"], bucket_url=path, file_glob="**/*.parquet", incremental=dlt.sources.incremental( "modification_date", initial_value=INITIAL_TS ), files_per_page=10, ) if last_ts: logger.info("Setting upper bound for modification_date to: %s", last_ts) files = files.add_filter(lambda r: r["modification_date"] < last_ts) files = files.add_map( lambda item: extract_partitions(item, schema=PARTITION_SCHEMA) ) return files | read_parquet_and_add_hive_columns(columns_mapper=columns_mapper) ``` I am using a transformer to read the files as Arrow batches and inject Hive partitioning data (extracted from the file path) as extra columns - I'm not sure if this is the only way. Despite using generators and processing data in batches, the memory consumption in the extract phase is surprisingly high. It seems the memory consumption grows when the size of the files that are being extracted increases. But I'd expect it to be steady, considering I'm iterating using batches. I had to set the number of extract workers to 1 and max parallel items as well: ``` EXTRACT__WORKERS: 1 EXTRACT__MAX_PARALLEL_ITEMS: 1 ``` This makes the whole process pretty slow, and still, consuming up to 2GB of memory seems a lot for what it is doing. Increasing number of extract workers or parallel items causes my PODs being terminated with OOM error. I can't afford to declare memory request to 4GBs. All in all, I'm mostly just move data from S3 to Bigquery. Any ideas where I can be doing things wrong? ### Expected behavior _No response_ ### Steps to reproduce Run the pipeline that extracts significant number of parquet files from S3 to any destination. Memory consumption is unreasonably high. ### Operating system Linux ### Runtime environment Kubernetes ### Python version 3.13 ### dlt data source S3 ### dlt destination Google BigQuery ### Other deployment details _No response_ ### Additional information _No response_

title: Support DECFLOAT type for the Snowflake destination
body:
### Feature description

Snowflake recently introduced a new data type, DECFLOAT, which stores numbers with variable precision. This is analogous to Oracle's NUMBER data type when precision and scale is not defined.

https://docs.snowflake.com/en/release-notes/2025/9_37#new-decfloat-data-type
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/data-types-numeric#label-data-type-decfloat

### Are you a dlt user?

Yes, I'm already a dlt user.

### Use case

In dlt, the default is to cast these values to `FLOAT`. You can cast them to `NUMBER` using `type_adapter_callbacks`, but that would require determining the effective precision and scale for each column individually. As a result, there is no single precision/scale pair that fits all columns, and computing per-column stats over all rows is not feasible.

So we effectively have two realistic options:

* `FLOAT` – arithmetic works out of the box, but there is a risk of precision loss 
* `STRING` – no precision loss, but you can’t do arithmetic in the destination without an extra conversion step.

A third alternative is `DECFLOAT`, which may offer precise representation while still supporting arithmetic in the destination.

### Proposed solution

_No response_

### Related issues

_No response_

title: Delta Lake merge fails with case-sensitive column names - DataFusion lowercases identifiers
body:
### dlt version

1.21.0

### Describe the problem

When using the **filesystem destination with Delta Lake table format**, merge operations fail with a schema
   error when the source data contains mixed-case column names (e.g., `UserCode`).

   The error indicates that DataFusion is lowercasing column names during the merge operation, causing a mismatch
    with the Delta table schema.

### Error Message

   ```
   _internal.DeltaError: Generic DeltaTable error: Schema error: No field named usercode.
   Column names are case sensitive. You can use double quotes to refer to the "usercode" column
   or set the datafusion.sql_parser.enable_ident_normalization configuration. Did you mean 'UserCode'?
   ```

### Expected behavior

Column names should be preserved with their original casing throughout the pipeline:
   - Source: `UserCode`
   - Parquet files: `UserCode`
   - Delta table schema: `UserCode`
   - Merge operation: should match `UserCode` to `UserCode`

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a dlt pipeline with filesystem destination and delta table format
   2. Set naming convention to "direct" to preserve column casing:
      ```python
      os.environ["SCHEMA__NAMING"] = "direct"
      dlt.config["schema.naming"] = "direct"
      ```
   3. Load data from a source with mixed-case column names (e.g., SQL Server with `UserCode`, `AccountId`)
   4. Use `write_disposition="merge"` or `write_disposition="replace"`
   5. Run the pipeline

## Investigation & Root Cause Analysis

   The issue appears to be in how dlt/deltalake/DataFusion handles column names during merge operations:

   1. **DataFusion SQL parser** normalizes identifiers to lowercase by default
   2. During merge, the generated SQL references columns without proper quoting
   3. This causes `UserCode` to be interpreted as `usercode`
   4. The Delta table schema has `UserCode`, so the lookup fails

   ### Related Issues

   - delta-io/delta-rs#1797 - "DeltaTable Merge throws in merging if there are uppercase in Schema" (fixed in PR
   #1954)
   - The error message suggests using `datafusion.sql_parser.enable_ident_normalization` configuration

   ### Potential Fix

   The merge operation should either:
   1. Quote all column identifiers in the generated SQL
   2. Set `datafusion.sql_parser.enable_ident_normalization = false` before merge operations
   3. Pass proper session config to DataFusion

   I tried setting this environment variable but it didn't help:
   ```python
   os.environ["DATAFUSION_SQL_PARSER_ENABLE_IDENT_NORMALIZATION"] = "true"
   ```

### Operating system

Linux

### Runtime environment

Local

### Python version

3.12

### dlt data source

Sql server 

### dlt destination

Filesystem & buckets

### Other deployment details

## Additional context

   - The issue occurs specifically during **merge/replace operations** when writing to Delta tables
   - First-time table creation works fine
   - The parquet files contain correct column casing
   - The Delta table _delta_log shows correct schema with mixed-case names
   - The failure happens in `dlt/common/libs/deltalake.py` -> `write_delta_table()` -> `write_deltalake()`"

### Additional information

_No response_

title: DuckLake support
body:
# Specs from rudolfix
(written by zilto, adapted from: https://github.com/dlt-hub/dlt/issues/2709#issuecomment-2958847943)

## Tasks
Create a new `ducklake` destination; it should inherit a lot of features from `duckdb`destination.

### Configuration
To allow to configure the catalog (a database) and storage (a filesystem), `DuckLakeCredentials` should derive from duckdb configuration and have the following signature

```python
@configspec(init=False)
class DuckLakeCredentials(DuckDbBaseCredentials):
    drivername: Final[str] = dataclasses.field(  # type: ignore
        default="ducklake", init=False, repr=False, compare=False
    )
    username: str
    password: TSecretStrValue = None
    database: str  # the name of the ducklake; required by DuckLakeSqlClient
    catalog: ConnectionStringCredentials  # for catalog; like postgres
    storage: FilesystemConfiguration  # for data;
```
Users will be able to configure the catalog and the storage from their `config.toml` and `secrets.toml`

### Resolve catalog and storage secrets
The duckdb connection needs credentials to the catalog ([postgres example](https://ducklake.select/docs/stable/duckdb/usage/choosing_a_catalog_database#postgresql)) and the storage ([supported storage](https://ducklake.select/docs/stable/duckdb/usage/choosing_storage))
- for storage, the duckdb destination already has a feature to get secrets from `FilesystemConfiguration` (i.e., the mechanism that allows to query S3 with duckdb)
- for catalog, we need to implement the function to get secrets from `ConnectionStringCredentials` 

### Configure DuckDB instance to support DuckLake
The class `DuckDbBaseCredentials` allows to set extensions, pragmas, global config, and local config. This allows to load the ducklake extension, but not to install it.

- `DuckLakeCredentials` should inherit from `DuckDbBaseCredentials`, but enforce the `ducklake` extension to be installed
- Set the current database to the ducklake name ([details here](https://github.com/dlt-hub/dlt/issues/2709#issuecomment-2948445610)).
- A lot of filesystem are [supported as duckdb extensions](https://ducklake.select/docs/stable/duckdb/usage/choosing_storage). `httpfs` supports all S3-compliant APIs. Also, it [supports python fsspec](https://duckdb.org/docs/stable/guides/python/filesystems.html). We can progressively add support here

### Out-of-scope
- ducklake [table maintenance](https://ducklake.select/docs/stable/duckdb/maintenance/recommended_maintenance); this should be done by the user directly against their ducklake instance

### Future work
- Add `ducklake` to `TTableFormat`
- DuckLakeClient should implement `SupportsOpenTables` to allow users to get authenticated catalog and table relation from the pipeline/destination ie. to do table maintenance. this is how delta and iceberg work.

# Original issue
### Feature description

we should support ducklake

User reported it currently doesn't work with our duckdb destination and we likely need to make some adjustments.

https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7335310253997096963?commentUrn=urn%3Ali%3Acomment%3A%28activity%3A7335310253997096963%2C7335375393492733952%29&dashCommentUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afsd_comment%3A%287335375393492733952%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A7335310253997096963%29

I've discovered the problem when syncing SQLDatabase (Spark/Thriftserver) -> Postgres, but from what I understood it probably affects other combinations. I've created a small script to demonstrate the problem: ```python import os import dlt from dlt.sources.sql_database import sql_table os.environ["SOURCES__SQL_DATABASE__CREDENTIALS"] = "hive://localhost:10000/myschema" os.environ["DESTINATION__POSTGRES__CREDENTIALS"] = ( "postgresql://user:password@localhost:5432/database" ) source = sql_table(schema="myschema", table="bool_hint_test", backend="pyarrow") source.apply_hints( columns={ "date_col": {"data_type": "date"}, "bool_col": {"data_type": "bool"}, "str_col": {"data_type": "text"}, } ) pipeline = dlt.pipeline( pipeline_name="bool_hint_test", destination="postgres", dataset_name="dlt_test", progress="log", ) print(pipeline.run(source)) ``` This is the SQL I'm using to create the source table: ```sql CREATE TABLE myschema.bool_hint_test ( date_col DATE, bool_col BOOLEAN, str_col STRING ) USING DELTA; INSERT INTO myschema.bool_hint_test VALUES (DATE '2024-01-01', TRUE, 'A'), (DATE '2024-02-10', FALSE, 'B'), (DATE '2024-03-20', TRUE, 'C'), (DATE '2024-04-05', NULL, 'D'); ``` ### Operating system Linux ### Runtime environment Local ### Python version 3.11 ### dlt data source SQLDatabase with Thriftserver (Spark) ### dlt destination Postgres ### Other deployment details _No response_ ### Additional information As far I've been able to track the error, it seems that when transposing the rows the wrong column order is being used. The root cause seems to be [this](https://github.com/dlt-hub/dlt/blob/ab0459aee30b02ba35465ed8ecfca8e12afac96a/dlt/sources/sql_database/helpers.py#L381) line: ```python columns_hints = resource.columns ``` The problem is that `resource.columns` seems to have a different column order as everything else (including the result of `table_to_resource_hints` that is used in other cases). It has a downstream effect on [this](https://github.com/dlt-hub/dlt/blob/ab0459aee30b02ba35465ed8ecfca8e12afac96a/dlt/common/libs/pyarrow.py#L1322) line: ```python columnar = transpose_rows_to_columns(rows, column_names=columns.keys()) ``` At this point, `rows` and `columns.keys()` have a different order for the columns. Screenshot from a debugging session: I'm not familiar enough with the project structure to be able to fix this immediately, but I can open a pull request if someone can give me pointers to the best solution.

title: Inconsistent Casing of SQL Server `UNIQUEIDENTIFIER` Between Full and Incremental Loads Causes Data Duplication
body:
### dlt version

1.17.1

### Describe the problem


When replicating a SQL Server table to a case-sensitive destination like Snowflake, there is a critical inconsistency in how `UNIQUEIDENTIFIER` columns are handled between the initial full load and subsequent incremental loads.

-   The **initial full load** (using a plain `sql_table` resource) converts `UNIQUEIDENTIFIER` values to **lowercase** strings.
-   The **incremental load** (using an `sql_table` resource with the `incremental` argument and a query_adapter_callback) preserves the **uppercase** string format.

Because the primary key of our table is a `UNIQUEIDENTIFIER`, this casing difference causes the `merge` write disposition to fail. When an update for an existing row arrives in the incremental load, Snowflake sees the uppercase key as a different value from the already-loaded lowercase key, resulting in the insertion of a duplicate row instead of an update. This breaks the replication logic and corrupts the destination table.


### **Investigation & Attempts to Fix**

We have determined that the lowercase conversion happens within the `pyarrow` backend, likely due to a content-based type inference that normalizes UUID-like strings. We attempted several solutions to force the initial load to produce uppercase keys, none of which were successful:

1.  **`pyodbc` Output Converter:** We implemented a custom converter at the database driver level to produce uppercase Python strings. **This failed** because the `pyarrow` backend's normalization happens later in the process and overrides the converter's output.

2.  **Schema Hinting (`apply_hints` & `type_adapter_callback`):** We tried to force `dlt` to treat the column as a generic `text` or `varchar` to prevent `pyarrow`'s special UUID handling. **This failed**, proving the normalization is based on the *content* of the data, not just the schema metadata.

3.  **`add_map()` Transformation:** We attempted to use `.add_map()` to apply an uppercase function. **This failed** because the `pyarrow` backend's bulk-processing optimization path completely bypasses this hook, and our mapping function was never executed.

### **Working Solution / Workaround**

The only successful method to prevent data duplication is to intercept the data after the initial extraction and manually correct the casing before the load step, using a `@dlt.transformer`.

The working pattern is as follows:
1.  Define the base `sql_table` resource. We accept that this will produce lowercase UUIDs on the initial load.
2.  Use `SQLAlchemy.inspect` to dynamically get a list of all `UNIQUEIDENTIFIER` column names from the source table.
3.  Define a `@dlt.transformer(data_from=...)` that takes the data from the base resource. This transformer loops through the detected column names and applies the `pyarrow.compute.utf8_upper()` function to each one.
4.  Critically, the parent `@dlt.source` function must **only `return` the final transformer resource**. This prevents `dlt` from also loading the (un-transformed, lowercase) data from the parent resource.

**Example of the working pattern:**
```python
@dlt.source
def mssql_replication_source():
    # Defines the base resource which extracts raw data
    base_resource = sql_table(..., backend="pyarrow")

    # Inspects DB to get a list of guid_column_names
    guid_column_names = get_guid_columns_from_db()


    # Defines the transformer that corrects the data
    @dlt.transformer(data_from=base_resource)
    def uppercase_transformer(data_chunk):
        # ... loops through guid_column_names and applies pc.utf8_upper() ...
        yield modified_chunk

    # Returns ONLY the final resource to prevent duplication
    return uppercase_transformer
```

### **Suggested Solution / Feature Request**

While the transformer pattern works, it adds significant boilerplate for what appears to be a fundamental data type handling inconsistency. This issue is critical as it silently causes data corruption on case-sensitive destinations.

Ideally, there should be a simpler, built-in way to ensure consistent type handling. For example:
-   A configuration option on the `sql_database` source to disable content-based type inference in the `pyarrow` backend.
-   Or, ensuring that the logic used in the incremental load path is the same as the initial load path for this data type.

This would make the pipeline much simpler and prevent this silent but critical data integrity issue.

### Expected behavior

The casing of `UNIQUEIDENTIFIER` columns should be handled consistently across both initial and incremental loads. The `merge` operation should correctly identify matching keys regardless of which load phase they came from, resulting in an update, not an insertion.


### Steps to reproduce

1.  **Source:** Create a table in SQL Server with a `UNIQUEIDENTIFIER` column as the primary key. Ensure the values are stored in uppercase.
2.  **Destination:** Configure a `dlt` pipeline to load to a Snowflake database.
3.  **Pipeline:**
    *   Create an initial load resource: `sql_table(..., backend="pyarrow")`.
    *   Create an incremental resource that reads from a change tracking table with the same schema: `sql_table(..., backend="pyarrow", incremental=..., query_adapter_callback=...)`.
    *   Set the pipeline's `write_disposition` to `"merge"`.
4.  **Execute:**
    *   Run the pipeline once to perform the initial full load. Observe that the primary keys in Snowflake are **lowercase**.
    *   Update a row in the source SQL Server table.
    *   Run the pipeline again to perform an incremental load.
5.  **Observe:** A new, duplicate row is inserted into the Snowflake table with an **uppercase** primary key, instead of merging with the existing lowercase row.


### Operating system

Linux

### Runtime environment

Docker, Docker Compose

### Python version

3.13

### dlt data source

sql_table

### dlt destination

Snowflake

### Other deployment details

_No response_

### Additional information

_No response_

title: feat: SQLGlot for DDL parsing
body:
Relates to #2561 

## Description
This maps dlt hints to SQLGlot DDL expressions. This internal feature could enable future usage:

### Table discovery
To enable `@dlt.transformation`, it's useful to know about tables manages outside of dlt.

It would make sense to discover from the `dlt.Dataset` API to add tables to its schema. Discovery should be limited to the same "database/dataset" namespace on the destination. Retrieving DDL from destination is a very cheap operation.

We would need a new hint for external tables.

tentative API.
```python
dataset = dlt.Dataset(...)
table_foo = dataset.table("foo")  # regular access
table_bar = dataset.table("bar")  # raise TableNotExist

dataset.discover()  # all tables within "database/dataset" namespace
dataset.discover("bar")  # single specific table
dataset.discover(["bar", "baz"])  # multiple specific tables 
dataset.discover(pattern="ba.*")  # unknown number using regex

table_bar = dataset.table("bar")  # succeeds because table is now in schema
```
This effect is persisted to the schema storage and the destination.

### Table creation
We have a lot of templated SQL strings for destination clients. We also use destination-specific SDK libraries.

Generating DDL from dlt hints could simplify internals and help with maintenance. This potentially simplifies supporting and testing new SQL backends.

More importantly, `dlt -> DDL` allows more powerful user configuration (e.g., create an index).

title: support custom backends, row loaders etc. via custom TableLoader in `sql_database`
body:
**Background**
We provide several ways to customize `sql_database` via callback that let you ie. to rewrite the queries. Here we are allowing for a deep customization by subclassing `TableLoader` that is responsible for execution of the query over already reflected SqlAlchemy table. Overriding this class will allow:
- implementing additional backends (ie. `adbc` fast arrow readers or ibis backend)
- implementing custom row readers ie. with pagination (#2432)
- implementing own retry mechanisms
- very deep customization of generated queries


**Implementation**
1. * [ ] design an internal interface that users are supposed to override in subclasses
2. * [ ] test the interface so we do not break users' code by chaning it
3. * [ ] allow to: easy add new backends and override row loading
4. * [ ] provide two examples in tests and docs: paginated loading + adbc backend for postgres / snowflake (we may merge it into OSS if works well)

title: [Bug] Parallel extraction for large MongoDB collections (Intra-resource parallelism)
body:
### dlt version

1.21.0

### Describe the problem

I am currently running an incremental pipeline extracting data from **MongoDB to Snowflake**, using arrow data item format. My collections are massive (exceeding **100 million rows**).

Currently, the extraction throughput is capped at approximately **1100 rows/second**. At this speed, initial loads and large incremental updates take an impractical amount of time.

I attempted to speed this up by enabling parallelism on the resource:
```python
# Pseudo-code of attempt
mongodb_collection(
    parallel=True,
    # ... logic ...
```

**Result:** The pipeline simply hangs/freezes and does not extract anything. It appears that `dlt` currently supports parallel execution *between* different resources, but not *within* a single resource (splitting one collection into multiple parallel extraction threads).

### Describe the solution you'd like
I would like native support for **intra-resource parallelism** for the MongoDB source.

Ideally, the MongoDB source could automatically (or via configuration) chunk the extraction based on:
1.  MongoDB `_id` ranges.
2.  Or a specific indexed field (e.g., `updated_at` or a numeric ID).

This would allow multiple threads/processes to extract from the *same* large collection simultaneously, significantly increasing throughput for massive datasets.


### Additional context
*   **Source:** MongoDB
*   **Destination:** Snowflake
*   **Data Volume:** > 100 Million rows
*   **Current Speed:** ~1100 rows/sec
*   **Behavior when `parallel=True`:** Process hangs indefinitely.

---


### Expected behavior

I would imagine it would chunk the extraction into multiple threads.

### Steps to reproduce

@dlt.source(
    name="mongodb_replication_append_only_source", max_table_nesting=0
)  # max_table_nesting wont work with data_item_format arrow, only with object
def mongodb_replication_append_only_source():

    new_rows_resource = mongodb_collection(
        connection_url=dlt.secrets.get("sources.mongodb.connection_url"),
        database=MONGO_DATABASE_NAME,
        collection=table_config["original_table_name"],
        incremental=dlt.sources.incremental(
            cursor_path=table_config["original_table_incremental_column"],
            on_cursor_value_missing="exclude",
        ),
        write_disposition="merge",
        data_item_format="arrow",
        chunk_size=int(os.environ["DLT_CHUNK_SIZE"]),
        parallel=True,
    )
    new_rows_resource.write_disposition = "merge"

    new_rows_resource.apply_hints(
        table_name=table_config["original_table_name"].upper(),
        primary_key="_id",
    )

    yield new_rows_resource


def main():
    pipeline_name = str(os.getenv("DLT_PIPELINE_NAME"))
    dataset_name = str(os.getenv("DLT_DESTINATION_DATASET_NAME"))
    pipeline_refresh = os.getenv("DLT_PIPELINE_REFRESH")

    if pipeline_refresh in {"drop_sources", "drop_resources", "drop_data"}:
        pass
    elif pipeline_refresh == "None" or pipeline_refresh is None:
        pipeline_refresh = None
    else:
        raise ValueError(f"Invalid Refresh: {pipeline_refresh}")

    dlt.config["destination.snowflake.keep_staged_files"] = False

    pipeline = dlt.pipeline(
        pipeline_name=pipeline_name,
        destination="snowflake",
        staging="filesystem",
        dataset_name=dataset_name,
        refresh=pipeline_refresh,
        progress="log",
    )

    dlt.config[f"{pipeline_name}.data_writer.file_max_bytes"] = 128 * 1024 * 1024
    dlt.config["load.delete_completed_jobs"] = True
    dlt.config["load.workers"] = int(os.getenv("DLT_LOAD_WORKERS", "20"))
    dlt.config["extract.workers"] = 10

    pipeline.sync_destination()


        load_info = pipeline.run(
            data=mongodb_replication_append_only_source(),
            loader_file_format="parquet",
        )
        logger.info(pipeline.last_trace)
        load_info.raise_on_failed_jobs()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

title: Bug: DLT + Athena breaks workgroups with Managed Query Results
body: ### dlt version dlt 1.21.0 ### Describe the problem I cannot use dlt with Athena when the Athena workgroup has Managed Query Results enabled because: - dlt requires `query_result_bucket` to be defined and non-null - Athena / PyAthena require the output location to be unset (None) when using a managed results bucket This results in a configuration deadlock: omitting `query_result_bucket` raises a `ConfigFieldMissingException`, while providing it causes Athena to reject the query. I.e., when this setting is on: ### Expected behavior It should be possible to use DLT with Athena even when results bucket is managed by Athena. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Create an Athena workgroup with Athena-managed query result configuration. 2. Configure DLT athena destination's `query_result_bucket` 3. If `query_result_bucket` is set to any string, even empty string, AWS raises exception: ``` dlt.destinations.exceptions.DatabaseTransientException: An error occurred (InvalidRequestException) when calling the StartQueryExecution operation: This query is not supported for workgroups with Managed Query Results enabled. 2026-01-22 18:03:03,613|[WARNING]|63218|139764178295680|dlt|load.py|complete_jobs:460|Job for organization_user.13b51452a0.sql retried in load 1769104933.3321931 with message An error occurred (InvalidRequestException) when calling the StartQueryExecution operation: This query is not supported for workgroups with Managed Query Results enabled. ``` 4. If `query_result_bucket` is omitted, DLT raises exception: ``` 'dlt.common.configuration.exceptions.ConfigFieldMissingException'> Missing 1 field(s) in configuration AthenaClientConfiguration: query_result_bucket ``` ### Operating system Linux ### Runtime environment Local ### Python version 3.11 ### dlt data source sql_database (postgres) ### dlt destination AWS Athena / Glue Catalog ### Other deployment details _No response_ ### Additional information I don't think there is a clean workaround. But, the problem can be fixed by making `query_result_bucket` optional (matching how PyAthena and AWS expect it to be): See: https://github.com/dlt-hub/dlt/blob/25cb8c718652d03e98a0ffc6ce1acc9ec70f6ee1/dlt/destinations/impl/athena/configuration.py#L23 ```bash # instead of query_result_bucket: str = None # this: query_result_bucket: Optional[str] = None ``` I can submit a PR shortly.

title: Redshift fix: Use correct view to determine schema existence
body:
## Description

Currently, the RedshiftSqlClient relies on `INFORMATION_SCHEMA.SCHEMATA` to determine if a schema exists. Unfortunately, this is not listing all the schemas (that's why there is this workaround, where the `public` schema is handled explicitly). The current way can cause errors, if the schema already exists, but is not listed in `INFORMATION_SCHEMA.SCHEMATA` when attempting to create it. 

To fix this, I've added added a condition that checks if the schema exists using `svv_redshift_schemas`, which lists schemas accessible to the current user (see https://docs.aws.amazon.com/redshift/latest/dg/r_SVV_REDSHIFT_SCHEMAS.html). I'm not aware if there are older Redshift versions, that do not have `svv_redshift_schemas`. Therefore, the old behaviour was preserved if the view does not exists. 

### Result
Redshift pipelines are less prone to intermittent “schema already exists” failures while keeping the previous behavior as a fallback when `svv_redshift_schemas` is not available/visible.

Code has been formatted using the black formatter. Please let me know if there's something else to be done.
